{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name= 54th Fighter Group (Air Defense) <center>[[File:Air Education and Training Command.png|60px]]</center> |image=[[File:F-16 1.jpg|290px]] |caption=[[F-16 Fighting Falcon]] as flown by the 54th Fighter Group |dates= 1941–1944, 1955–1958, 2014 |country={{flag|United States|23px}} |allegiance= |branch={{air force|USA}} |type= |role=[[fighter aircraft|Fighter]] Training |size=800 people<ref name=Luke54FG>{{cite web |url= http://www.luke.af.mil/units/54thfightergroup.asp |title=54th Fighter Group|date=|publisher=56th Fighter Wing Public Affairs|deadurl=no |accessdate=July 17, 2015}}</ref> |command_structure=[[Air Force Reserve Command]] |current_commander= |garrison= [[Holloman Air Force Base]] |ceremonial_chief= |colonel_of_the_regiment= |nickname= |patron= |motto= |colors= |march= |mascot= |battles=[[American Theater of World War II]] [[Asiatic-Pacific Theater|Pacific Theater of Operations]] |notable_commanders= |anniversaries= |decorations=[[Distinguished Unit Citation]] |battle_honours= <!-- Insignia --> |identification_symbol=[[File:54th Fighter Group.PNG|175px]] |identification_symbol_label=54th Fighter Group emblem <small>(Approved 8 March 1957)</small><ref name=54FGfacts>{{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=21506 |last1=Robertson|first1=Patsy|title=Factsheet 54 Fighter Group (AETC)|date=2014-04-21|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=April 23, 2014}}</ref> |identification_symbol_2=[[Image:54thfg-emblem.jpg|165px|]] |identification_symbol_2_label=Emblem of the 54th Fighter Group as originally approved<ref name=Maurer228>Maurer, ''Combat Squadrons''. p. 228-229</ref> }} The '''54th Fighter Group''' is an active [[United States Air Force]] unit, stationed at [[Holloman Air Force Base]], New Mexico and assigned to the [[56th Fighter Wing]] of [[Air Education and Training Command]]. The group was reactivated in March 2014.
The group was first activated as the '''54th Pursuit Group''' during the buildup of the [[United States Army Air Corps|Air Corps]] just prior to [[World War II]]. It served in Alaska during the [[Aleutian Islands Campaign]], earning a [[Distinguished Unit Citation]]. It then returned to the United States and served as a training unit.
The group was again activated in 1955 as part of [[Air Defense Command]]'s Project Arrow, replacing the [[500th Air Defense Group]]. It served in the [[air defense]] role until 1958 when it was inactivated.
The group was activated once again as a training unit for the [[General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon]] in 2014.
==History==
===World War II=== [[File:42d Fighter Squadron P-39E Adak Alaska.jpg|thumb|left|42d Fighter Squadron P-39F at Adak, Alaska]]
The group was activated as the '''54th Pursuit Group''' (Interceptor) at the beginning of 1941 at [[Hamilton Air Force Base|Hamilton Field]], California. with the [[42d Flying Training Squadron|42d]], [[56th Fighter Squadron|56th]], and [[57th Fighter Squadron|57th Pursuit Squadrons]] assigned.<ref name=Maurer228/><ref name="M CU 116">Maurer, ''Combat Units''pp. 116–117</ref><ref name=Maurer195>Maurer, ''Combat Squadrons''p. 195</ref><ref name=Maurer227>Maurer, ''Combat Squadrons''. p. 227</ref> It trained with [[Curtiss P-36 Hawk]]s and [[Curtiss P-40 Warhawk]]s, then moved to [[Paine Field|Everett Army Air Field]], where it served as a part of the [[air defense]] force for the northwest Pacific coast during the first few months of [[World War II]].<ref name="M CU 116"/> The [[group (military aviation unit)|group]] and its [[squadron (aviation)|squadrons]] were redesignated as [[fighter aircraft|fighter]] units in May 1942.<ref name=Maurer228/><ref name="M CU 116"/><ref name=Maurer195/><ref name=Maurer227/>
The air echelon, equipped with [[Bell P-39 Airacobra]]s, served in Alaska against the Japanese forces that invaded the Aleutian Islands during the summer of 1942, and for these operations the group received a [[Distinguished Unit Citation]].<ref name="M CU 116"/>
[[File:P-51B 42d Fighter Squadron Hillsborough Army Airfield FL 1944.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|54th Fighter Group P-51 at Hillsborough AAF]]
The air echelon returned to the US in December 1942 and rejoined the group, which had been assigned to Third AF in Louisiana, and became a replacement training unit (RTU) for [[North American P-51 Mustang]] pilots.<ref name="M CU 116"/> RTUs were oversized units training individual [[aviators|pilots]] or [[aircrew]]s.<ref>Craven & Cate, Vol. VI, Introduction, p. xxxvi,</ref> In early May 1943, the group began a split operation, with [[headquarters]] and the 56th and 57th Fighter Squadrons relocating to [[Bartow Army Air Field]],<ref name=Maurer228/><ref name="M CU 116"/><ref name=Maurer227/> Florida, while the 42d was at [[Hillsborough Army Air Field]].<ref name=Maurer195/> The AAF was finding that standard military units, based on relatively inflexible tables of organization were proving less well adapted to the training mission. Accordingly, a more functional system was adopted in which each base was organized into a separate numbered unit.<ref>Craven & Cate, Vol. VI p. 75, The Organization and its Responsibilities, Chapter 2 The AAF</ref> As a result, in 1944 the group was disbanded as the AAF converted to the AAF Base Unit system.<ref name="M CU 116"/> The units at Bartow were replaced by the 340th AAF Base Unit (Replacement Training Unit, Fighter),<ref>''See'' {{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/169/647.xml |title=Abstract, History Bartow AAF May–Jul 1944|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> while those at Hillsborough transferred their mission, equipment, and personnel to the 343d AAF Base Unit (Replacement Training Unit, Fighter).<ref>''See'' {{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/173/299.xml |title=Abstract, History Hillsborough AAF May–Jun 1944|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref>
===Cold War=== [[File:42d Fighter-Interceptor Squadron North American F-86L-50-NA Sabre 52-10073.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|54th Fighter Group F-86 Sabre at Greater Pittsburgh Apt]] In 1955, the group was redesignated as the '''54th Fighter Group''' (Air Defense) and activated at Greater Pittsburgh Airport<ref name="M CU 116"/> to replace the [[500th Air Defense Group]]<ref>Cornett & Johnson, p. 81</ref> as part of ADC's Project Arrow, which was designed to bring back on the active list the fighter units which had compiled memorable records in the two world wars.<ref>Buss (ed), Sturm, Denys & McMullen, p.6</ref> The group assumed host responsibilities for the USAF portion of the airport and was assigned a USAF Dispensary,<ref name=54USAFD1955>''See'' {{cite web |url= http://www.airforcehistoryindex.org/data/000/406/786.xml |title=Abstract, History 54 Dispensary July–Dec 1944|date=|publisher=Air Force History Index|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref> Air Base Squadron and Materiel Squadron<ref name=CJ155>Cornett & Johnson, p. 155</ref> to fulfill this responsibility. Because Project Arrow was also intended to reunite fighter squadrons with their former groups, the [[42d Flying Training Squadron|42d Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]], which was stationed at [[O'Hare Airport]] moved to Pittsburgh and assumed the personnel and equipment of the 500th group's [[71st Fighter-Interceptor Squadron]], including its [[radar]] equipped and [[rocket (weapon)|rocket]] armed [[North American F-86 Sabre]]s. The [[squadron (aviation)|squadron]] transitioned into [[data link]] equipped F-86Ls in the spring of 1957 for interception control through the [[Semi-Automatic Ground Environment]] system and flew them until the group and squadron were inactivated in early 1958.<ref name=cj115>Cornett & Johnson, p.115</ref>
===Present day=== The group was reactivated in March 2014 at [[Holloman Air Force Base]], New Mexico. It is an [[F-16 Fighting Falcon]] training unit and will be associated with the [[56th Fighter Wing]] at [[Luke Air Force Base]].<ref name=54FGjoins>{{cite web |url= http://www.12af.acc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123403234 |last1=Cannon|first1=A1C Chase|last2=Arlan|first2=|title=54th Fighter Group joins Team Holloman|date=2014-03-12|publisher=49th Fighter Wing Public Affairs|deadurl=no |accessdate=March 14, 2014}}</ref> It has approximately 800 personnel assigned and trains about 160 F-16 pilots annually.<ref name=Luke54FG/>
==Lineage== * Constituted as '''54th Pursuit Group''' (Interceptor) on 20 November 1940 * Activated on 15 January 1941 : Redesignated as '''54th Fighter Group''' (Single Engine) on 15 May 1942 : Disbanded on 1 May 1944. : Reconstituted and redesignated '''54th Fighter Group''' (Air Defense), on 20 June 1955 * Activated on 18 August 1955 : Inactivated on 8 January 1958 : Redesignated '''54th Fighter Group''' on 20 February 2014 * Activated on 1 March 2014<ref name=54FGfacts/><ref name=54FGjoins/>
===Assignments=== * [[1st Fighter Wing|1st Wing]], 15 January 1941 * [[2d Interceptor Command]], 9 April 1941 * [[5th Air Support Command]], 31 January 1942 * [[3d Interceptor Command]] (later III Fighter Command), 18 April 1942 – 1 May 1944 (Air echelon deployed to [[Eleventh Air Force]], 1 June 1942 – 30 November 1942) * [[4708th Air Defense Wing]], 18 August 1955 * 30th Air Division, 8 July 1956 – 8 January 1958 * 56th Fighter Wing, 1 March 2014 – present<ref name=54FGfacts/><ref name=54FGjoins/>
===Stations=== * Hamilton Field, California, 15 January 1941 * Everett Army Air Field, Washington, 26 June 1941 * [[Harding Field]], Louisiana, 31 January 1942 * Bartow Army Air Field, Florida, 11 May 1943 – 1 May 1944 * Greater Pittsburgh Airport, Pennsylvania, 18 August 1955 – 8 January 1958 * Holloman Air Force Base, New Mexico, 1 March 2014 – present<ref name=54FGfacts/><ref name=54FGjoins/>
===Components=== '''Operational Squadrons''' * [[42d Pursuit Squadron]], later 42d Fighter Squadron, 42d Fighter-Interceptor Squadron, 42d Fighter Squadron: 15 January 1941 – 1 May 1944 ; 18 August 1955 – 8 January 1958 * [[56th Fighter Squadron|56th Pursuit Squadron]], later 56th Fighter Squadron: 15 January 1941 – 1 May 1944<ref> {{cite web |url= http://www.afhra.af.mil/factsheets/factsheet.asp?id=16853 |last1=Endicott|first1=Judy G.|title=Factsheet 56 Training Squadron (AETC)|date=2010-06-16|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency|deadurl=no |accessdate=May 5, 2012}}</ref> * [[57th Pursuit Squadron]], later 57th Fighter Squadron: 15 January 1941 – 1 May 1944 * [[311th Fighter Squadron]]: 1 March 2014 – present<ref name=54FGfacts/> * [[314th Fighter Squadron]]: c. 14 July 2015 – present<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.acc.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123453438&source=GovD |title=314th FS activation|date=July 14, 2015|publisher=Air Combat Command Public Affairs|deadurl=no |accessdate=July 17, 2015}}</ref>
'''Support Units''' * 54th USAF Infirmary:<ref name=54USAFD1955/> 18 August 1955 – 8 January 1958 * 54th Air Base Squadron: 18 August 1955 – 8 January 1958 * 54th Aircraft Maintenance Squadron: 14 March 2014 – present<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.luke.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-140924-017.pdf |last1=Robertson|first1=Patsy|title=Factsheet 54th Aircraft Maintenance Squadron|date=August 7, 2014|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency (edited by 56th Fighter Wing Public Affairs)|deadurl=no |accessdate=July 17, 2015}}</ref> * 54th Materiel Squadron: 18 August 1955 – 8 January 1958<ref name=CJ155/> * 54th Operations Support Squadron: 1 March 2014 – Present<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.luke.af.mil/shared/media/document/AFD-140924-020.pdf |last1=Robertson|first1=Patsy|title=Factsheet 54th Operations Support Squadron|date=August 8, 2014|publisher=Air Force Historical Research Agency (edited by 56th Fighter Wing Public Affairs)|deadurl=no |accessdate=July 17, 2015}}</ref> * 54th Maintenance Squadron: c. 14 July 2015 – Present<ref name=Luke54FG/>
